We switched again. We revamped the way we reported to the Board. It used to be that the Board talked about the finances of the Bank once a year, and that was typically at the end of July, the beginning of August, their last meeting before the summer recess, where they were asked to approve the financial statements of the Bank (which were as of June 30 because that was the end of the fiscal year), needed to be approved before they went on August recess because if not, we wouldnâ€˜t have been able to publish the annual report of the Bank, which of course had to be ready for the annual meetings in September. . Their annual stockholdersâ€˜ meeting is in April. We close our books on the 30th of June, and we have our annual meeting in September, and we lose our Board to the summer recess at the beginning of August.
So, you know, it was sort of the last day where they were going off on recess that we asked them to approve the allocation of the net income of the Bank and of course, in the day where there was never really a constraint because it was more or less politics but it was not a matter of where thereâ€˜s a finite amount that can be used, all of a sudden, after 1998, 1999, they needed to understand, â€•Well, whatâ€˜s the capital situation of the Bank? And whatâ€˜s the risk position of the Bank?â€–
And so we started to move into sort of the March-April framework a mid-termâ€”what we called a medium-term financial outlook reviewâ€”and said, â€•No, no. Your time to have your really deep discussion about the financial future of the Bank is not when youâ€˜re signing off on the financial statements and allocating the income. Itâ€˜s got to be three months before that so that we can begin the process of developing a consensus around how we should allocate the income of the Bank, because if we donâ€˜t develop the

consensus starting in April, thereâ€˜s no way weâ€˜re going to get resolution at the end of July because this is going to be contentious.â€– And we needed to socialize the situation.
BECKER: What were the sources of contention?

It never told you how much or how you were supposed to calculate it.
Thatâ€˜s when we started using all of these techniques that we had vetted by the Wise Men to say, â€•Well, hereâ€˜s how we calculate how much. What is the minimum amount of capital we need?â€– And guess what? In several years we werenâ€˜t ableâ€”we didnâ€˜t have enough capital to meet it. So we said, â€•Well, but over time we think we will.â€–
And so the Board had to come along and say, â€•Well, Iâ€˜m signing off on using income for something other than reserves when the reserves arenâ€˜t adequate.â€–
And we said, â€•Well, look, over a three-year time period you can do this.â€–
So there was a use for reinvestment in the Bank. There was a use of funds to give to IDA and to give to HIPC. Then there were, of course, other things. In the Former Republic of Yugoslavia, reconciliation and reconstruction funding. Or East Timor or West Bank and Gaza or capacity-building in Africa. Grant-making, if you will. And, of course, historically the Bank always had enough funds to make grants because the risks that it was protected against never materialized because all of our borrowers always were uni- directional. They were always becoming more creditworthy. So we always had kind of leftover funds.

And then we had the countries from Latin America and East Asia who were saying, â€•No, no, no. The money should be going into the reserves of the Bank so itâ€˜s there in case we need to borrow. The Bank is paying the cost of what the rich countries should be paying out of their budgets not out of the Bankâ€˜s income.â€– And so they said, â€•No, no. If thereâ€˜s extra money in the Bank, you should be giving us a rebate on our interest costs.â€– So you had to dance around this allocation of income, some of which would go to IDA and HIPC, some of which would go to give rebates or waivers on interest charges, some of which would go back into the grant- making capacity of the Bank, and some of which would have to go into reserves. And the one thing that we could always get that was always non-contentious was if we said itâ€˜s going to get reinvested in the Bank, no one ever said boo!
But once you gave it to one set of constituents, immediately the Board started acting not as fiduciaries of the Bank but as representatives of their constituencies, and saying,

â€•Well, look, if youâ€˜re going to start divvying up the goodies, I want to make sure that Iâ€˜m getting it.â€– And so it was really very important because we had one sessionâ€”and I believe it was â€˜97, the income-allocation discussion in â€˜97â€”which included, as I recall, a price increase on loans of 25 basis points. I mean, weâ€˜d be in big trouble.
And so over time I took greatâ€“I used as my metric of success the degree of consensus at the time of income allocation, meaning that the Board understood the risk position of the Bank, they understood what the Bank needed in terms of capital, and that we came up with a reasonably consensual allocation of the balance of the resources. And increasingly they also wanted to see where the budget was coming from as well. So, in fact, we created something called an Integrated Resources Framework which started showing up in the strategic paper that went to the Board in March which was sort of the kickoff for the budget season as well, where they said, â€•No, no, no. We want to see the whole picture, not just the admin budget. We want to see whatâ€˜s happening to our capital, we want to see whatâ€˜s happening to our income, we want to know what youâ€˜re going to do with the income because we have a great interest in seeing all this happen.â€– And increasingly what they also wanted to see was the interplay between IBRD and IDA because they understood, â€•Look, IDA charges our financing more than a third,â€– and it got close to half, maybe over half by now, based on the formula IDA charges are paying for the admin expenses of the Bank, â€•but then again, the Bank turns around and gives them 300 million of a grant as part of IDA replenishments and then thereâ€˜s IDA and then thereâ€˜s HIPC.â€–

And then we had all sorts of questions of, â€•Well, you know, again, if IDA goes to grants, whoâ€˜s going to pay the freight here?â€–
BECKER: Over the long term.
PERLIN: Over the long term. Many of the countries, a lot of Middle Eastern countries, at least their representatives on the Board, said, you know, â€•This Bank is in trouble. It does so out of being leveraged because of the way the Bank was created was as a leveraged financial institution. I always used to say to people, I tried to speak in very plain language to them, I said, â€•Look, have you tried to buy a car recently?â€–
The answer was, â€•Yes,â€– okay?
â€•Did the salesman offer you cash back or zero percent financing?â€–
And the answer was, â€•Yes.â€–
â€•Well, itâ€˜s the same thing. We can give them a low rate financing, or we can give them cash. There is an economic and financial equivalent between those two. And, quite

frankly, theyâ€˜re both the same, and whether or not we give a grant or a loan doesnâ€˜t matter. Weâ€˜re going to be able to give fewer grants than we can give loans because of leverage and so forth, but guess what? If we give a grant and therefore canâ€˜t give them as much money as we could have had we loaned it to them, theyâ€˜re going to go out and borrow the money from somebody else at market rates. And, in effect, theyâ€˜re going to put together the grant and the market-rate lending and say, â€—Oh, we just got a subsidized rate.â€˜ Well, I can give you the subsidized rate for the same amount. I mean this is a very dysfunctional conversation, folks.â€–

PERLIN: It is. By politics, but itâ€˜s not by financial realities and, unfortunately, not necessarily by what makes most sense from a development standpoint. Many more peopleâ€”we unlocked the secrets, which we needed to do in order to make sure we were being both responsible and responsive during the crisis. And if the expectation that I have going forwardâ€”and you can see in some of the speeches Iâ€˜ve madeâ€”which is I think volatility is here to stay, it seems to me the Bank needs to operate where its Board, including the new Board members who are constantly coming on stream, they need to understand: How does the Bank make money? How does the Bank take risk? What are the limits, what are the trade-offs? Can I put money into an admin budget thatâ€˜s going to create knowledge? Or should I put it into the reserves thatâ€˜s going to allow lending? Or should I give the money away?
And the answer is: I donâ€˜t know. Iâ€˜m just a finance guy. I can quantify your choices. The way you make your ultimate choice, of course, unfortunately, is going to be politics and everything else, but it should also be based on what you think the returns are going to be. Thatâ€˜s where you have to look at the development side of the Bank and say to them, â€•Where am I going to get the biggest development bang for the buck? Am I going to get it from knowledge? But I feel like I left the Bank in a position to understand the interplay between its structure as a financial institution and its mission as a development institution, and recognizing that you need the framework of one to help guide the decisions of the other. And maybe at some point in timeâ€”and I donâ€˜t know the answer to this one, as much as I have talked to you and Iâ€˜ve spoken publicly about the genius of the founders of the Bank to have structured something that was so unfortunately complicated but out of that complexity some flexibilityâ€”Iâ€˜m not sure that it is infinitely flexible. There may come a time?
BECKER: This was one of my last questions: What do you see?
PERLIN: And you know what? I think itâ€˜s a decision that people will shy away from if they can. Itâ€˜s going to be a tough decision. Politics are going to get in the way. And it was pretty clear to me that Jim Wolfensohn, in the waning years of his presidency, was not going to be able to resolve this issue. I think itâ€˜s got to be something that a new president coming in would have to say, â€•Iâ€˜m going to make this the hallmark of my presidency, is that weâ€˜re going to figure out where weâ€˜re going as an institution.â€–
I think what Jim did certainly was to refocus the institution towards being development focused and poverty-alleviation focused and corruption-reduction focused and all sorts of things. I just found $30 billion that I can put against it,â€– now, you canâ€˜t do it overnight because you have to unwind the lending book at the Bank.

Itâ€˜s here. Now you need to work out some of the IBRD-IDA and some of the IBRD-IFC issues. But by and large, youâ€˜re here. But if you decide that over the long haul that being a lending institution for development is no longer the way

youâ€˜re going to have your impact, there may be a limit as to how malleable your financial structure really is.â€–
I donâ€˜t have a view exactly about what the right answer is. I think people are going to have to face the question. We did have some analyses. Iâ€˜m not sure I gave them to you because Iâ€˜m not sure I found them. But we did some sort ofâ€”no, I did give them to you. We found someâ€”we did some thirty-year scenarios about, â€•Gosh, if we stop lending tomorrow, weâ€˜re going to eat into our capital over time.â€–
So I feel strongly that the Bank Group--emphasis on â€•Groupâ€–--needs to assess its mission and its business model, its modus operandi, its governance, and say, â€•Are we aligned from financial institution to development institution the way that Bank was aligned in 1944?â€– Because, boy, oh boy, it was aligned then. But they had the luxury of creating the Bank at a time when they knew what their development model was, which was big infrastructure lending needing lots of foreign exchange at a time the capital markets were discontinuous. And, boy, this Bank kept changing over and over and over. But it never needed to change its finances or its structure or its governance. I donâ€˜t know whether it is positioned well for the future. I think thatâ€˜s for future presidents and future Boards to decide.
And frankly, you know, I look back and say one of the legacies I am proudest of is I gave them the tools with which to have that understanding and that dialogue, recognizing that ultimately itâ€˜s going to be a negotiated decision in a political context. But theyâ€˜re going to go so not with their heads in the sand.
BECKER: Why did you decide to leave in July 2003?
PERLIN: I left in July 2003. It was largely a personal decision. A couple of reasons. I guess I had a bit of the ten-year itch. It was ten years since I had arrived. Also, in terms of my own personal standing, my children were growing, and oddly enough I always felt that as challenging as the job of the Bank was, I was always able to marry it with what I considered to be a pretty good family life, particularly when I was in the finance side of the Bank. And with my kids going off to college, I no longer felt that I needed to keep the same sort of balance.
CapitalOne, as a company, came to me, as they had nine years earlier when they went public, and offered me the same job, that of CFO, at a time where I felt I was probably within two years of retirement from the Bank anyway. My feeling was that I needed to leave at least a year before Jim so somebody else had a chance to kind of come up to speed or I needed to stay at least a year after Jim left in order to help induct his successor, not quite knowing where that successor might come from and what their position might be. But my feeling was that I was going to leave either a year before Jim or a year after Jim. And when CapitalOne came to me and made me a very compelling financial offer, along with an opportunity to help shape this company because itâ€˜s in a very important crossroads. It just became a Fortune 200 company. Itâ€˜s buying a bank. Itâ€˜s going into a whole new realm. Itâ€˜s geography was very important to me. As I think I mentioned off
Gary L. Perlin June 24 and 25, 2004â€”Final Edited  60
line to you yesterday, itâ€˜s a Virginia-based company, both Richmond and McLean, which happens to align with my two homes in Fairfax County and in Williamsburg. And so it was not a decision to leave the Bank, contrasting it with my previous major career decision, which was to leave Fannie Mae not because I knew where I was going but because it was time to leave. In this case it was a decision to join CapitalOne, which triggered my decision to depart from the Bank. But I can say, I think in good conscience, that CapitalOne came to me in 1998 and offered me this job as well, but it was in the midst of the Asia crisis, and I said, â€• Iâ€˜m sorry. I canâ€˜t leave right now.â€–
I felt that the condition of the Bank in the spring of 2003 was such that there was enough kind of blue sky. We were making it through the Argentina crisis. I felt that we had made significant progress in laying out to the Board and to our shareholders and senior management what choices the Bank needed to make. I felt that I could leave the Bank in good hands. I had no qualms about leaving the Bank at that moment.
I did feel that the next important thing I could have done at the Bank would have been perhaps to derive a more long-term decision about how the Bank was going to reconcile its financial institutional goals with its development goals. So I felt I had contributed about as much as I was going to be able to contribute, that there was probably going to be a period of a couple of years before real next steps were going to be taken. And so again, the question was called by the offer I received from CapitalOne, but when I balanced it, it came out with a much more opportune time for me to take an early retirement from the Bank before it was too late to start a new career outside. So it was absolutely a demand-pull, but at a time that I felt was a responsible time to leave the Bank.

doc.abstracts: In June 2004, Gary L. Perlin was interviewed on behalf of the World Bank Group Archives oral history program by William H. Becker. During his tenure at the Bank from 1975 to 2003, Mr. Perlin worked in the following areas: as a young professional (1975-1976); in the eastern Africa region as an economist (1976-1978); in the financial sector development department as director (1993-1996); and in the treasurer's department as vice president and treasurer (1996-1999) and as senior vice president and chief financial officer (1999-2003). His transcript concerns his work on economic projects in Peru, nutrition for Colombia, agriculture for Zambia, and on reports for Botswana and Sudan. As treasurer he developed a new financial products and services department. As senior vice president in finance he was responsible for all funding and cash management and investment portfolio management, as well as interest rate risk management.
